items.message: High river levels today and overnight may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 31 January and 01 February 2026. This information is correct as of 3:00pm on Saturday 31 January 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 17cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has areas with some water on the road. There are currently no issues on Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourse. This message will be updated by 8:00am on Sunday 01 February.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The river level at Huish Episcopi is currently 8.71m. The drain level at Huish Episcopi is 8.54m and stable. Flooding will affect the Langport to Muchelney road if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Draycott road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel has been opened. Further light showers are forecast today, Saturday 31st January, and on Sunday and Monday. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 01 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Western Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is high at Fittleworth and Lodsbridge near Selham. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect Fittleworth Mill, nearby properties, and isolated mill properties near Lodsbridge. Between Liss and Midhurst river levels are near normal. Only isolated showers are forecast Saturday. River levels should only rise a small distance between Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. River levels should begin to fall at Lodsbridge by 11:00 31/01/2026, and in Fittleworth by 21:00 31/1/2026. However, more rain is forecast Sunday, which could cause the river to rise again. The Western Rother should not rise as high as recent events. Only minor flood impacts are expected to affect fields, roads, and gardens. River levels are likely to be higher than normal through to Monday. More rain is forecast Monday, which will cause the river to rise again. Keep in place any flood protection products you may have. Including in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. This message will be updated by 14:00 01/02/2026.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
High tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 7:00AM to 11:00AM on Sunday 1 February 2026. 
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. Locations most affected will be coastal roads and footpaths. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it, is for high water level of 1.24 mAODN at 9:00 am tomorrow morning, with south easterly force 4 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level). Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide times. 
We are closing flood gates and closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid coastal roads, footpaths and carparks, which may be flooded and refer to local authority websites for road closures. 
This message will be updated by 1:00PM on 01 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence

Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.1m to 3.6m on 01/02 AM;  Cae Howel 3.3m to 3.8m on 01/02 AM. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 01 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.71m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.73m. Cutts Road and New Road are both closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 is also closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor, and additional pumps are operational at Northmoor. Further light showers are forecast today, Saturday 31st January, and on Sunday and Monday. We are monitoring the situation closely and staff are checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 01 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Worcestershire
items.message: River levels are falling but remain high which may lead to some flooding. Flooding is possible on 31 January 2026. Flooding may affect low lying land & roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury; including Dog Lane Bewdley, Stourport, Diglis & Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains affect the racecourse & Worcester CCG. PLP should be installed. New St Gate closed at Upton upon Severn. Measured peaks:- Worcester peaked at 4.01m at 18:45, Wednesday 28 January 2026, Diglis peaked at 3.87m at 18:30, Wednesday 28 January 2026, Kempsey Yacht Club peaked at 6.05m at 18:45, Wednesday 28 January 2026, and Saxons Lode peaked 4.63m at 07:00, Thursday 29 January 2026. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 1 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mansbridge and Riverside Park
items.message: Flooding is possible on 31/01/2026 and 01/02/2026. High tide at Southampton is forecast at 22:00 and 23:30 on 31/01/2026 at 4.60 metres Chart Datum (1.87 mAOD). For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the incoming tide will prevent river from flowing to sea. This may flood the access road and the car park near to the White Swan Pub at Mansbridge. Footpath flooding may also affect Riverside Park. Only isolated showers are forecast during Saturday (31/01/2026) and Sunday (01/02/2026). River flows are expected to reduce over the weekend. Tide levels and flooding impacts will be similar at the next high water at 10:15 and 12:15 on Sunday (01/02/2026). We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have, including defences around the White Swan pub. This message will be updated by 16:00 01/02/2026.

River levels are slowly receding but water levels in the Loe Valley remain high.   

The weather remains unsettled and further rain is forecast on Monday.  

Catchments are wet and rivers levels remain high. 

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts and Warnings if necessary.  

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.   

This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 1 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor Pumping Station is 7.71m. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45m. The Drain level at Currymoor Pumping Station is currently 7.73m. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Water is flowing out of Currymoor over Athelney Spillway and the A361 remains closed. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if the Drain level reaches 8.30m. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Further light showers are forecast today, Saturday 31st January, and on Sunday and Monday. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 01 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lox
items.message: The River Lox is high following Friday's rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, roads, and gardens near the top of the River Lox, including isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Also fields, roads and gardens near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Only isolated showers are forecast Saturday. River levels will fall. However more rain is forecast Sunday and Monday, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible, particularly next week. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst. This message will be updated by 14:00 01/02/2026.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: High river levels on Saturday are expected to cause minor flood impacts. At Alverstone, the river level is slowly falling. No further impacts are expected here. At Sandown, the level is slowly rising in response to rainfall (18mm) recorded Friday (30/01/2026). Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will continue throughout Saturday (31/01/2026). Ditches around Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain while river levels are high. Only isolated showers are forecast Saturday (31/01/2026) and Sunday (01/02/2026). River levels and flood risk should begin to reduce in Sandown by 13:00 Saturday (31/01/2026). We are operating Bembridge sluices. Avoid low lying roads near rivers‚ which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 14:00 01/02/2026.

However more rain is forecast Sunday and Monday, which will cause the river to rise again and further flooding could be possible, particularly next week. items.description: Lower Arun
items.message: The River Arun is high, but falling following the past week's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads, and gardens will continue to affect the A29, gardens of properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Over high tides (09:45 and 22:30 on 31/01/2026 and 10:45 01/02/2026) water will be high up banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley, Houghton, and Arundel, but as tides are currently low, property flooding is not expected in these communities. Isolated showers are forecast Saturday, and small amounts of rain predicted on Sunday. However, we predict that river levels at Pulborough will keep falling. Although, river levels will not fall far, and with more rain forecast Monday, as well as higher tides, further river rise and flood risk could be possible next week. We are closely monitoring the situation and our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce flood risk. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel. This message will be updated by 18:00 01/02/2026.

items.description: River Thames at Thames Ditton Island

floodArea.county: Greater London, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
High tides combined with high river flows from upstream overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the early hours of 1 February 2026. 
The next high tide is expected at Thames Ditton at 01:30 on 1 February 2026 and is forecast to reach between 5.41m - 5.71m. The following high tide is expected at 14:00 on 1 February 2026 and is forecast to reach between 5.49m - 5.79m. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 01 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding for the Iwerne
items.message: Rising groundwater levels are expected to cause flooding.  Flooding is expected from 19th January 2026 onwards.  Groundwater levels in Cranborne Chase remain high. Areas that could be affected include: Iwerne Minster.  Further rain is forecast over the next few days. Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Residents may experience inundation of septic tanks and sewer systems. Properties may experience flooding in cellars in affected areas. Flooding of roads is expected, please take care when driving.  We are closely monitoring the situation .  If you have a pump, make sure it is working and switched on. Think about alternative power sources in case of power cuts Please do not drive through floodwater as this may cause bow waves.  This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 2 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

On Friday 30/01/2026 and Saturday 31/01/2026, up to 15mm of rain is forecast on each day. Sunday 01/02/2026 and Monday 02/02/2026, are expected to be drier. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley in the coming days then groundwater levels at the borehole in Meonstoke will rise into next week. If not, then levels may peak over the weekend. items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message: The River Yeo level remains high and the drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.54m and stable. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.30m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road about 8.8m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping will start at Huish Episcopi and Westover stations once river levels allow. The Parrett Relief Channel has been opened. Further light showers are forecast today, Saturday 31st January, and on Sunday and Monday. We are monitoring the situation closely. Staff are checking the condition of flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 01 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message:
Water levels remain high and continued flooding is expected on Saturday and Sunday. Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads around Moorland including Horlake, Saltmoor, Fordgate and Chadmead. 

Levels in the River Tone and on Currymoor are stable although still very high. The River Tone is still too high for pumping at Currymoor station. Athelney spillway is still running into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. 

Further light showers are forecast today, Saturday 31st January, before a band of rain crosses the area on Sunday. Monday is forecast to be drier, but rivers remain extremely responsive to further rain. 

Act on your flood plan if you have one. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1pm on 01 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Denton
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 30/01/2026, after above average rainfall in January. 
Minor flood impacts could affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. A small amount of water may appear on Denton Road. Groundwater at Houndean Bottom borehole is expected to stop rising around the 31/01/2026. However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday, with the suggestion of more rain next week. Further groundwater rise could be possible next week, which may cause water to flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. If rain continues, flood impacts may remain until mid February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , including rainfall, groundwater and forecasts. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 02 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message:

However, small amounts of rain are forecast Friday and Saturday. More rain is suggested next week. If further rain occurs further groundwater rise could cause more water to flow along Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden, between Cooks Lane and Barley Mow in Walderton, the B2146 near Woodlands Lane. Towards the end of the first week of February water could also affect cellars in Stoughton and Walderton. 
We are closely monitoring the situation , including rainfall, groundwater and forecasts. 
Don't put yourself or others at risk . Avoid roads that flood (Stoughton, Walderton). Ensure pumps work.

items.description: Middle Avon at Fordingbridge
items.message: This is a Flood Warning Update. River levels are steady but remain high at the Downton Iron Bridge river gauge due to to recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding is still possible, and areas most at risk include Roman Quay, Timbermill Court and Bowerwood in Fordingbridge. The weather remains unsettled, with further showers forecast overnight tonight and tomorrow. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 1 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Wallops
items.message: High river levels on Saturday are expected to cause minor flood impacts. River levels are currently falling, following dry weather Friday night. Flooding could affect low lying land, including gardens at Rectory Lane and Rookery Lane, Broughton. Only isolated showers are forecast Saturday (31/01/2026) and Sunday (01/02/2026). River levels and flood risk will continue to reduce over the weekend. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will ensure the river is kept free of reported blockages. Stay away from floodwater - it can contain hidden dangers such as open manhole covers‚ sewage and chemicals. This message will be updated by 14:00 01/02/2026.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message:
High groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from Monday 02/02/2026 because of a very wet January 2026. 
In the last 24 hours, the groundwater level at Finchdean has risen by 67cm. It is possible that pumps which prevent water from entering property may be required from Monday 02/02/2026. During heavier rainfall events, surface water could affect property. On Friday 30/01/2026 and Saturday 31/01/2026, up to 15mm of rain is forecast on each day. Sunday 01/02/2026 and Monday 02/02/2026, are expected to be drier. Groundwater levels will rise into next week. If heavy rain affects the valley in the coming days, then it is possible that roads and more properties could be affected later in the week. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and liaising with the Flood Action Group. 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 05 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
